title: 105_hr4608
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to extend duty-free treatment until June 30, 2000. Certain entries made between July 1, 1998, and the enactment of the Act will be liquidated or reliquidated as duty-free. Entries made between July 1, 1998, and the enactment of the Trade Act of 1974 will be liquidated or reliquidated as duty-free. Requests for liquidation or reliquidation must be filed with the Customs Service within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 2. Duty drawback for MTBE amended to include 2909.19.14. Effective upon enactment and applies to claims filed after. SEC. 3. Substitution of finished petroleum derivatives. Section 313(p)(1) of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to allow drawback as described in paragraph (4). Section 313(p)(2) is amended to clarify requirements for qualified articles. Section 313(p)(3) of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to define qualified articles, specifying primary forms under Note 6 to chapter 39 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States. The amended Section 313(p)(3) of the Tariff Act of 1930 defines qualified articles as specified in Note 6 to chapter 39 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States. The transferred merchandise described in the certificate of delivery or manufacture shall be the qualified article for this section. The amended Section 313(p)(3) of the Tariff Act of 1930 defines qualified articles as specified in Note 6 to chapter 39 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States. A party issuing a certificate of delivery must certify to the Commissioner of Customs that they will not exceed the eligible drawback amount and will maintain appropriate records. Additionally, there are modifications to subparagraphs (B) and (C) regarding articles eligible for drawback. The amendments to Section 313(p)(4)(B) of the Tariff Act of 1930 allow for drawback claims to qualify under subsection (j). These changes will take effect retroactively and waive the 3-year requirement for claims filed within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. RELIQUIDATION OF CERTAIN NUCLEAR FUEL ASSEMBLIES. The Secretary of the Treasury shall reliquidate specified entries as duty-free and refund any duties paid upon proper request within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. LIQUIDATION OR RELIQUIDATION OF CERTAIN WATER RESISTANT WOOL TROUSERS. SEC. 5. LIQUIDATION OR RELIQUIDATION OF CERTAIN WATER RESISTANT WOOL TROUSERS. Notwithstanding the Tariff Act of 1930, the Secretary of the Treasury shall reliquidate duty-free entries upon request within 90 days of this Act and refund any paid duties. The affected entries are specified in subsection (b). SEC. 6. DUTY ON CERTAIN IMPORTATIONS OF MUESLIX CEREALS. Before January 1, 1996, any entry or withdrawal of mueslix cereal classified under a special column rate for Canada can be liquidated or reliquidated under a different rate, with excess duties refunded. After December 31, 1995, entries or withdrawals of mueslix cereal classified under a special column rate for Canada can be adjusted to a different rate, with excess duties refunded, including interest. SEC. 7. EXPANSION OF FOREIGN TRADE ZONE NO. 143. The Foreign Trade Zones Board will expand Zone No. 143 to include areas near Chico Municipal Airport as requested by Sacramento-Yolo Port District. The expansion does not exempt Port of Sacramento from any requirements under the Foreign Trade Zones Act. SEC. 8. CUSTOMS USER FEES. Section 13031 of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 is amended to include additional preclearance activities and the collection of fees for passengers aboard commercial vessels. This includes providing salaries for inspectional positions and expanding services to up to 50 full-time equivalent positions. Section 13031 of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 is amended to include fees for passengers arriving on commercial vessels from outside the US. The fee is $5 for each passenger, except for those arriving from specific places where the fee is $1. The Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 is amended to allocate $50,000,000 in fiscal year 1999 for automated commercial systems within the Customs Service. Additionally, an advisory committee will be established by the Commissioner of Customs consisting of representatives from various transportation industries subject to fees under the Act. The advisory committee, established by the Commissioner of Customs, will advise on issues related to inspectional services of the Customs Service, including time periods for services, number and deployment of officers, fees, and proposed fees. The committee's views will be considered by the Commissioner in decision-making. SEC. 9. MARKING OF CERTAIN SILK PRODUCTS AND CONTAINERS. Section 304 of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include new subsections regarding the marking requirements for certain silk products and goods. The amendment also includes a conforming amendment to update references within the Act. The amendments made by this section apply to goods entered on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, with changes to subsections.
